entry.title: Re: SAP Learning hub access
entry.content:
Hi krcc1,

Both Foundational Certification and Stay Certified/Delta Exams require a qualified/current SAP Learning Hub License.

If you have purchased one, please let me suggest to:

First: Confirm your eligibility by going to learning.sap.com - > log-in using the credentials used during Learning Hub Activation process -> Click on My Learning - > Click on Subscription Menu on the left.  Here you can check your actual Learning Hub Edition and components (e.g. Certification Attempts remaining + Learning System).   See attached snippet of what a similar page will look like for an eligible SAP Learning Hub Edition (mine is employee edition, other qualifying editions will be Premium, Partner Edition, etc.) 

Second: If you do not see your SAP Learning Hub Premium or Partner Edition or any other qualified commercial edition of Learning Hub, the possible reasons are either activation has not gone through successfully or there are issues with the User ID.  Try to trace the Order and re-check activation. 

Third: If the correct eligible SAP Learning Hub Edition and components (Certification Attempts) reflects in your account as active but you're still experiencing page re-direct upon attempt to take the Stay Certified Exam, it's best to raise a support incident via SAP Learning help center - Category: Technical Queries. 

Hope this helps!

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud creation of new Special G/L
entry.content:
Hello @Liyana ,

No ‚Äî in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you cannot create new Special G/L indicator types.
Only SAP-delivered special G/L indicators are allowed, and you cannot create additional ones through configuration, CBC, SSCUI, or expert configuration.

In Public Cloud, SAP strictly controls the financial configuration to ensure standardization, compliance, and upgrade stability. Therefore, many classic FI customizations (like creating new Special G/L indicators) are locked.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: UPA
entry.content:
Hello @VSNGupta 

Yes ‚Äî SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ALWAYS runs with Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA) activated by default.
You cannot deactivate it, and you cannot activate it manually ‚Äî it is embedded into the Cloud system from the first activation.

Few Limitations due to UPA being mandatory:-

‚Ä¢ Cannot customize valuation views beyond SAP delivery
‚Ä¢ No freedom to disable ledger-dependent valuation
‚Ä¢ All financial postings replicate to multiple ledgers when relevant
‚Ä¢ No classic FI/CO reconciliation structures

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: S4Hana Public cloud - Ex. rate diff. acc. incomplete
entry.content:
Hello @rekafulop ,

In Public Cloud, the system checks Exchange Rate Difference Accounts for any G/L account used in bank statement postings.

If the G/L account 0011001020 is missing:
-Realized Gain Account
-Realized Loss Account
in the Account Determination for Exchange Rate Differences, the system raises this error.

Unlike On-Premise, Public Cloud does not allow defining separate transaction keys.
Instead, it uses the Central Finance Configuration ‚Üí Automatic Account Determination via SSCUIs.

 

TopicDetails
Where to FixCBC / SSCUI: Define Accounts for Exchange Rate Differences (Automatic Account Determination).
How to Fix (Steps)1. Open Manage G/L Account Master Data ‚Üí G/L 0011001020 ‚Üí check Account Determination Group. 2. Go to SSCUI: Set Exchange Rate Difference Accounts. 3. Maintain: Realized Gain Account and Realized Loss Account for that same determination group.
Fields to Maintain‚Ä¢ Realized Exchange Gain Account (P/L G/L) ‚Ä¢ Realized Exchange Loss Account (P/L G/L)
PrerequisiteBoth gain/loss accounts must be valid P&L accounts, not balance sheet accounts.
Impact if Not MaintainedBank statement posting will fail for any FCY movement affecting G/L account 0011001020.
What Else to Check if Still Fails‚Ä¢ G/L account currency settings ‚Ä¢ G/L is properly assigned to determination group ‚Ä¢ Gain/loss accounts are active and not blocked for posting ‚Ä¢ Bank account clearing assignment accuracy
Temporary WorkaroundNone ‚Äî this config is mandatory. Only valid fix is to assign gain/loss accounts.
Final Fix Summary

Determine the Account Determination Group for G/L 0011001020 ‚Üí maintain its exchange rate gain & loss accounts ‚Üí reprocess bank statement.

 


If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Terms of payment -3% discount in 10 days from invoice...
entry.content:
Payment Term: ‚Äú3% discount in 10 days from invoice date or 45 days EOM‚Äù

This means the customer/vendor has two options for paying the invoice:

Option 1: Take Cash Discount

If payment is made within 10 days from the invoice date

Then they get 3% discount on the invoice amount

‚Üí This is the cash discount period.

 

Option 2: Pay Full Amount

If they don‚Äôt take the discount

Then the full amount is due 45 days after the end of the month (EOM) of the invoice date

‚Üí This is the net due date.

 

Example for clarity

Invoice Date: 10 January 2025

Discount Option:

Pay on or before 20 January 2025

‚Üí Pay 97% of invoice amount.

Net Payment Option:

End of invoice month = 31 January 2025

Add 45 days ‚Üí 17 March 2025

‚Üí Pay 100% of invoice amount.

 

Configuration in SAP represents this in Payment Terms (OBB8)

OBB8 ‚Äì Payment Terms Header

Discount Percentage (SKTO1): 3%

Discount Days (ZTAG1): 10 days

Net Terms: 45 days from EOM

‚Üí Set ‚ÄúBaseline Date Calculation = Fixed Day=31‚Äù

‚Üí Set net days = 45

entry.title: How to Write to Space-Owned Tables (FSDM_DEMO) in SAP Datasphere ?
entry.content:
Hello,

We have a local table DQ_RESULTS in the FSDM_DEMO space in SAP Datasphere.
Using the Datasphere UI, we can load data into this table through Data Flows or Transformation Flows without any issue.

However, we want to implement a stored procedure that should:

  1. Read records from the view DQ_RULE_GENERATED_VW, which contains dynamically generated SQL statements (as column values).

  2. Execute each of these SQL statements dynamically.

  3. Insert the results into the DQ_RESULTS table in the FSDM_DEMO space.

Since SAP Datasphere does not support creating stored procedures directly in the UI, we attempted to build the procedure using the HANA Database Explorer.
But the database user available to us does not have the required SELECT/INSERT privileges on the FSDM_DEMO schema, so the procedure cannot read from or write to the table.

We also tried creating a Database User Group (DUG).
The DUG schema that gets created does not have read/write access to the DQ_RESULTS table in FSDM_DEMO.

We tested multiple users:

  • FSDM_DEMO# ‚Üí does not have read/write access to DQ_RESULTS

  • DWCDBUSER# ‚Üí has only SELECT, no INSERT privileges

So far, none of the technical options allow us to run a stored procedure or write into FSDM_DEMO tables.

Additional Issue

We are also connecting to the DQ_RESULTS table via a Python script using the DWCDBUSER# user.
Again, this user can read the table but cannot write to it.

All our tables, views, and flows are created inside the FSDM_DEMO space, so we need a supported way to write to these Datasphere-owned objects from:

  • Stored procedures

  • Database User Group schemas

  • External scripts (Python)

At the moment we are completely blocked due to insufficient privileges, and it‚Äôs unclear whether such write access is intentionally restricted by design or if we are missing a configuration step.

Question

Is there any supported approach in SAP Datasphere that allows:

  • dynamic SQL execution,

  • writing results into a space-owned table,

  • or enabling external tools (like Python) to write into space-managed objects?

If stored procedures, DUG schemas, and tenant-level users are intentionally restricted from inserting into space object tables, guidance on alternative supported patterns would be very helpful.

Any help or clarification would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Mayura

entry.title: Custom logic for Payment media file
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We use KOINH (Account Holder Name) and ZSTRA (Street) fields in Payment file. Since we have Field length 60 and in payment file only supported 35 Characters so we use custom logic to split First 35 char to one field and the rest to another field in Payment file. The split works for KOINH but not working for ZSTRA.

TYPES: ty_char60 TYPE c LENGTH 60,
ty_char35 TYPE c LENGTH 35,
ty_char25 TYPE c LENGTH 25.

DATA: lv_source TYPE ty_char60,
lv_first TYPE ty_char35,
lv_second TYPE ty_char25,
lv_cutoff TYPE i VALUE 35,
lv_index TYPE i,
lv_space_index TYPE i..

lv_source = paymentdata-koinh.

IF strlen( lv_source ) <= lv_cutoff.
paymentcustomerfields-zref02 = lv_source.
paymentcustomerfields-zref03 = ''.
ELSE.
lv_space_index = 0.

" Search backwards for the last space before or at position 35
DO lv_cutoff TIMES.
lv_index = lv_cutoff - sy-index.
IF lv_source+lv_index(1) = ' '.
lv_space_index = lv_index.
EXIT.
ENDIF.
ENDDO.

" If no space was found, cut at 35
IF lv_space_index = 0.
lv_space_index = lv_cutoff.
ENDIF.

lv_first = lv_source(lv_space_index).
lv_second = lv_source+lv_space_index.

paymentcustomerfields-zref02 = lv_first.
paymentcustomerfields-zref03 = lv_second.
ENDIF.

Kindly support.

entry.title: Re: S/4 HANA 2023 | Enable Dynamic Feature Controls and Side Effects in RAPM based Fiori Apps
entry.content:
@MioYasutake Apologies for the delayed reply.

In 2021 version, we have an older syntax for the implementation of side effects, support for DDIC based CDS views, no mandatory usage of USE STRICT in the Behavior Definition to enforce the rules etc., Whereas In 2023 version, we have improved features in the RAP framework such as DDIC based CDS views are no longer supported and mandatory use of CDS entities, mandatory usage of USE STRICT in the Behavior Definition etc., Also, due to the process improvements in the RAP framework, there is no support for adding the field controls directly using side effects syntax in the behavior definition in the backend.

For other differences, I have found below details for your reference.

Feature                                          SAP S/4HANA 2021                          SAP S/4HANA 2023

Dynamic Feature ControlBasic instance/global featuresField-level granular control
Field ControlOperation-level (entity-based)Individual field-level control
Side Effects - ScopeLimited field dependenciesFull support for fields, entities, associations
Side Effects - DefinitionMostly in UI annotationsBehavior definition + annotations
Action Side EffectsManual implementationDeclarative action-based side effects
Association RefreshNot supportedFully supported via targetEntities
Validation IntegrationSeparateIntegrated with affectedValidations
Declarative vs CodeMore code requiredMore declarative, less code

entry.title: Re: Outlook about SAP Document AI - Channels and workflow...
entry.content:
Hi Thomas Madsen Nielsen

Thank you for reaching out. 
With newly delivered features - email ingestion and workflows, you can achieve automated processing of emails. Following steps need to be followed:
1. Set up your inbox from which emails need to be fetched
2. Create an Inbound channel of type Mail and provide the details of configured mailbox
3. While creating the channel, if you just want to process email body and process them using schema, you can choose Target Type as "Schema Version" and select an active schema to be used to process the email body
4. If you want to process email attachments or attachments+body, then choose Target Type as "Workflow Version" and select an active workflow to be used

Here are some useful links:
1. Create schema - https://help.sap.com/docs/document-ai/sap-document-ai/schemas (Choose to either enable a content schema or create a new schema)
2. Create workflow - https://help.sap.com/docs/document-ai/sap-document-ai/workflows
3. Set up mailbox for email ingestion - https://help.sap.com/docs/document-ai/sap-document-ai/configuring-inbound-channels-technical-information
4. Create inbound email channels- https://help.sap.com/docs/document-ai/sap-document-ai/create-inbound-channel

Please let us know if there are additional queries.
Thank you
Komal Narsinghani

entry.title: How to display the project stock related G/L account in "Project Cost Report"?
entry.content:
We have recently met some questions regarding how to display the project stock related G/L account in "Project Cost Report".

I've documented my testing process below and hope it provides some helpful insights.

1. Create a project with correct project profile.

The project stock is only supported for projects with project profile 'Investment Projects' and 'Project with Revenue'. Refer to help document.
Hence, the first step is to create a project and WBS elements with project profile 'Investment Projects' or 'Project with Revenue' in "Project Control - Enterprise Projects" app.
In my sample, I create one project with 'Investment Projects'. I have also tested  this with 'Project with Revenue', and the results are the same.

2. Create material demand for demand type 'Project Stock, Direct Purchasing'.

Go to "Manage Project Demand" app, create material demand for the WBS Element you create in step 1. Make sure the Demand Type is 'Project Stock, Direct Purchaing'. When the demand is requested, Purchase Requisition and Item will be generated automatically.

3. Create Purchase Order from the generated Purchase Requisition.

In "/nME21n", create PO from the PR you generated in step 2. The G/L account will be associated to inventory project stock automatically.

4. Make sure the G/L account is maintained in the Financial Statement Version (FSV) YPS2 as item 61, under the semantic tag Project/Sales Order Cost (PRSLS_STCK).

5. The Inventory G/L account will be displayed in "Project Cost Report".

 

Select the line item, and click 'View Details', you'll see the G/L Account and it's document.

entry.title: Creating Sales Orders in S/4HANA Using RAP BO & EML ‚Äì Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
In modern SAP landscapes, integration plays a key role. Businesses often need to create Sales Orders automatically from external systems like e-commerce platforms, mobile apps, or middleware (CPI/PO) ‚Äî without manual effort in transactions like VA01.

Traditionally, developers used BAPIs (e.g., BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2) or custom RFCs to achieve this. While functional, these approaches are not clean-core compliant, hard to maintain, and don‚Äôt align with SAP‚Äôs future-ready development model.

In this blog, we‚Äôll see how to achieve the same goal ‚Äî create Sales Orders programmatically ‚Äî but in a modern and upgrade-safe way using:

  • RAP BO (Business Object) for clean-core, model-driven design
  • EML (Entity Manipulation Language) for easy create/update operations
  • REST Framework to expose our logic as a lightweight, consumable API

 

Why we are doing this:

  • To allow external systems to create Sales Orders directly in SAP via an API
  • To follow SAP Clean Core principles ‚Äî no direct DB or BAPI calls
  • To enable reusable, testable, and upgrade-safe backend logic
  • To demonstrate how RAP and EML can replace traditional coding patterns

 Benefits:

  1.  Fully OData/REST compliant and can be consumed by any system
  2.  Clean-core compatible ‚Äì future-proof against upgrades
     Uses standard RAP BO (I_SalesOrderTP) ‚Äì minimal custom logic
  3.  Lightweight & fast ‚Äì no heavy RFC/BAPI dependency
     Easy to extend ‚Äì can include partners, pricing, schedule lines later

 Note:
SAP provides standard Sales Order APIs in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, but here we‚Äôll focus on building our own lightweight API using RAP BO and EML, purely for learning and flexibility.

Prerequisites

Before you begin, ensure:

  • You have access to an S/4HANA system (2020+ recommended)
  • RAP model and Service Binding are configured
  • The service endpoint is active and reachable in /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE
  • You understand basic ABAP classes and interfaces

 What We‚Äôll Build

We‚Äôll create:

  1. A REST API to trigger Sales Order creation
  2. Backend logic that uses RAP BO and EML to insert data
  3. A JSON payload/response for easy integration with other systems

RAP BO Used

I_SalesOrderTP

Object Directory Entries Created

Object Name

Type

Description

ZS4CL_DEMO_SO_HANDLE

Class

HTTP Handler (API entry point)

ZS4CL_DEMO_SO_RESOURCE

Class

Resource class containing business logic

REST API

Service

Endpoint exposed for external consumption

 Step 1 ‚Äì Create HTTP Handler Class: ZS4CL_DEMO_SO_HANDLE

This class will handle all incoming API requests and route them to our main business logic class.

Implementation

CLASS zs4cl_demo_so_handle DEFINITION PUBLIC INHERITING FROM cl_rest_http_handler.

  PUBLIC SECTION.

    METHODS if_rest_http_handler~get_root_handler REDEFINITION.

ENDCLASS.



CLASS zs4cl_demo_so_handle IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD if_rest_http_handler~get_root_handler.

    DATA(lo_router) = NEW cl_rest_router( ).

    lo_router->attach(

      iv_template = space

      iv_handler_class = 'ZS4CL_DEMO_SO_RESOURCE'

    ).

    ro_root_handler = lo_router.

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

What this does:
This class doesn‚Äôt perform any business logic itself ‚Äî it simply routes incoming API calls to the resource class, where we‚Äôll handle them.

 Step 2 ‚Äì Create Resource Class: ZS4CL_DEMO_SO_RESOURCE

This is where all the fun happens!
We‚Äôll redefine two methods:

  • IF_REST_RESOURCE~GET ‚Üí Get call for CSRF token ( no code required )
  • IF_REST_RESOURCE~POST ‚Üí Our main logic for creating the Sales Order

 

 Define the Data Structures

We‚Äôll define a local structure to hold the JSON request data:

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_so_create_rap_bo,

         SalesOrderHeader             TYPE I_SalesOrderTP,

         SalesOrderItem               TYPE I_SalesOrderItemTP,

       END OF ty_so_create_rap_bo.



DATA: BEGIN OF ls_response,

        status     TYPE string,

        salesOrder TYPE I_SalesOrderTP-salesorder,

        message    TYPE string,

      END OF ls_response.

 Deserialize Incoming JSON Request

When the API is called, it will send data in JSON format.
We‚Äôll read and convert that JSON into an ABAP structure:

DATA(lv_request_serialize) = mo_request->get_entity( )->get_string_data( ).



/ui2/cl_json=>deserialize(

  EXPORTING json = lv_request_serialize

  CHANGING  data = ls_sales_order_payload_rap_bo

).

 Create Sales Order Using EML

Here we use EML (Entity Manipulation Language) to insert a Sales Order and its item in one go.

MODIFY ENTITIES OF i_salesordertp

  ENTITY salesorder

  CREATE FIELDS ( salesordertype salesorganization distributionchannel organizationdivision soldtoparty )

  WITH VALUE #( ( %cid = 'H001'

                  %data = VALUE #(

                    salesordertype        = ls_so_header-salesordertype

                    salesorganization     = ls_so_header-salesorganization

                    distributionchannel   = ls_so_header-distributionchannel

                    organizationdivision  = ls_so_header-organizationdivision

                    soldtoparty           = ls_so_header-soldtoparty

                  ) ) )



  CREATE BY item

  FIELDS ( product requestedquantity )

  WITH VALUE #( ( %cid_ref = 'H001'

                  %target = VALUE #( ( %cid = 'I001'

                                       product = ls_so_item-product

                                       requestedquantity = ls_so_item-requestedquantity ) ) ) )



  MAPPED DATA(ls_mapped)

  FAILED DATA(ls_failed)

  REPORTED DATA(ls_reported_modify).

 Commit and Return Response

Once the Sales Order is created successfully, we commit the entities and send a response back to the API caller.

COMMIT ENTITIES BEGIN

  RESPONSE OF i_salesordertp

  FAILED DATA(ls_save_failed)

  REPORTED DATA(ls_save_reported).



IF ls_save_failed-salesorder IS INITIAL.

  ls_response-message = 'Order Created'.

  ls_response-salesorder = ls_mapped-salesorderitem[ 1 ]-salesorder.

  io_entity->set_header_field( iv_name = 'status' iv_value = '200' ).

ELSE.

  ls_response-message = 'Failed due to data issue'.

  io_entity->set_header_field( iv_name = 'status' iv_value = '400' ).

ENDIF.



COMMIT ENTITIES END.

Finally, send a JSON response:

DATA(json_response) = /ui2/cl_json=>serialize( data = ls_response ).

mo_response->create_entity( )->set_string_data( json_response ).

mo_response->set_header_field(

  iv_name  = 'Content-Type',

  iv_value = 'application/json'

).

 Sample JSON Payload

Here‚Äôs what your external system (like Postman or CPI) will send:

{

  "SalesOrderHeader": {

    "SalesOrderType": "ZBV1",

    "SalesOrganization": "0700",

    "DistributionChannel": "B1",

    "OrganizationDivision": "00",

    "SoldToParty": "0004100648",

    "RequestedDeliveryDate": "20250923"

  },

  "SalesOrderItem": {

    "Product": "000000000000040078",

    "RequestedQuantity": "1"

  }

}

Sample Response

Success:

{

  "status": "200",

  "salesOrder": "0000123456",

  "message": "Order Created"

}

Failure:

{

  "status": "400",

  "message": "Failed due to data issue"

}

üéØSummary

In this blog, we learned how to:

  • Create a custom REST API for Sales Order creation
  • Use RAP BO (I_SalesOrderTP) and EML for clean-core logic
  • Handle JSON serialization/deserialization
  • Return structured HTTP responses

This approach is clean-core compliant, future-proof, and easily extendable for real-world business needs.

üîßNext Steps

If you want to take this further:

  • Add authentication (e.g., OAuth 2.0 or Basic Auth)
  • Extend your RAP BO to include partners, pricing, schedule lines
  • Add error handling and detailed logging
  • Expose this API securely to SAP BTP or external systems

Conclusion

Using RAP and EML, we can build lightweight, modern, and scalable APIs directly in S/4HANA ‚Äî without breaking the clean-core principle.
This approach bridges traditional ABAP development with modern REST API design, giving us flexibility and control.

entry.title: How to secure your integration flows in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
SAP Integration Suite is basically SAP's way of letting you connect everything, from your old-school SAP systems to your cloud apps. Think of it as the super glue holding all your tech together.

It has tools like:

  • Cloud Integration (CPI) ‚Äì for creating and handling iFlows
  • API Management ‚Äì for handling, and guarding your APIs
  • Open Connectors ‚Äì for third party integrations (like Salesforce, Google, etc.)
  • Integration Advisor ‚Äì for making B2B connections easier

If you're using iFlows to send important business info, security has to be a priority from the get-go.

Why Protecting iFlows Matters

Your iFlows might be sending:

  • Customer info
  • Financial records
  • Employee details
  • Proprietary business logic

If those flows aren't secure, you could face:

  • Data leaks
  • Compliance violations (like GDPR, HIPAA)
  • System crashes or attacks

Unsecured integrations put your business at serious risk.

Key Areas to Focus On

1. Who Gets Access

Start by making sure only the right people can get to your iFlows.

I suggest:

  • Using OAuth 2.0 for secure API access with tokens
  • Using client certificates for connections between systems or B2B stuff

Don't:

  • Use basic authentication, especially with hardcoded passwords. If you still are, try to switch ASAP.

Also, give people the right roles. Use role-based access control in SAP BTP Cockpit and only give people the access they need.

2. Keep Things Encrypted

Use HTTPS with TLS 1.2 or higher for all data transfers.

For on-premise systems, use SAP Cloud Connector with a list of approved IP addresses and TLS.

For sensitive payloads, consider message-level encryption or PGP steps within your iFlow.

Avoid saving sensitive data unless you really have to. SAP encrypts data at rest by default, but you should still control what data you keep.

3. Design with Security in Mind

Security should be a normal part of your design, not something you add at the end.

Some good ideas:

  • Check all incoming data (use JSON/XML validator steps)
  • Clean up inputs used in Groovy or JavaScript
  • Avoid dynamically evaluating user inputs in scripts
  • Use content filters to block or route unwanted messages
  • Use the Groovy script sandbox to stop access to risky Java classes

4. Secure Your APIs

If you're exposing iFlows as APIs through SAP API Management, make sure to:

  • Use OAuth 2.0 or API key validation
  • Apply rate limiting and quotas
  • Enable IP filtering
  • Check incoming JWTs to maintain identity context
  • Use threat protection to stop XML/JSON injection attacks

5. Monitor and Track Everything

Enable logging and monitoring to spot problems early.

  • Use SAP Audit Log Service to track changes and access events.
  • Set up alerts for suspicious activity, like huge payloads or frequent errors.
  • Use SAP Cloud ALM or integrate with tools like Splunk or Dynatrace to see what's going on.

Logs and monitoring are key for fixing problems and proving you're following the rules.

 

A Real World Example

A factory accidentally exposed an iFlow with basic authentication info that was hardcoded. An attacker found it and got into confidential shipping data.

The problem went on for days because no one was watching or getting alerts.

The result was a data leak, fines, and a damaged reputation.

This shows why even small mistakes can lead to big trouble.

Secure DevOps

Security doesn't stop when you deploy.

  • Use SAP Transport Management Service (TMS) to move iFlows across environments with approvals
  • Keep secrets in the SAP BTP Keystore or Secure Parameter Store
  • Don't put passwords in scripts or config files
  • Automate testing, including tests for bad situations and security regression tests

Identity Propogation

In hybrid integrations, maintaining user identity across systems is important for audit trails and authorization.

Some options:

  • JWT tokens for cloud-based situations
  • SAML assertions for on-premise SAP systems
  • OAuth2SAMLBearerAssertion in SAP API Management for secure token exchange

Threat Modeling

Use the STRIDE model to identify risks in your integration design early:

1. Spoofing: Use OAuth 2.0, client certificates

2. Tampering: Use digital signatures, message hashing

3. Repudiation: Enable and retain audit logs

4. Information Disclosure: Use TLS, apply data masking

5. Denial of Service: Apply rate limiting, IP restrictions

6. Elevation of Privilege: Use role-based access control

Metrics to monitor

Track these things to see how secure you are:

  • Failed login attempts
  • Outdated or insecure connections
  • Hardcoded passwords in iFlows
  • How long it takes to fix problems
  • Time to react to security alerts

Use dashboards or connect to your SIEM tools to stay informed.

Security Checklist

Before you deploy an iFlow, make sure that:

1. HTTPS and TLS 1.2+ are enforced

2. Authentication is done with OAuth or certificates

3. No credentials are stored in scripts

4. Sensitive data is encrypted or hidden

5. Role-based access controls are set up

6. Monitoring and alerts are configured

7. API throttling and quotas are in place

8. Input validation and error handling are implemented

Helpful SAP guides:

SAP Integration Suite Security Guide: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite#operate_task-security

Identity and Access Management: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/identity-and-access-management?version=CLOUD

Final Thoughts

Security is more than just a setting. It's a way of thinking.

Whether you're building, designing, or taking care of iFlows, make security a daily habit. Check your integrations often. Look at your logs. Fix problems fast.

Because in today's connected world, your integrations are more than just tech. They're the foundation of your business. Keep them secure.

entry.title: Fixed Asset procurement in Ariba Guided Buying & S/4HANA Public Cloud integrated environment
entry.content:
The blog shares tips and tricks and configuration settings in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for Fixed Asset procurement, where the Purchase Requisition originates in Ariba Guided Buying and subsequent processes are executed in S/4HANA Cloud Public edition.

Background

A typical scenario for Fixed Asset (e.g. Laptops, Printers etc.) procurement begins with Purchase Requisition creation and approval in SAP Ariba Guided Buying. This purchase requisition is replicated in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and converted into Purchase Order with Account Assignment Category (AAC) = A-Asset and sent to the supplier.  At the time of physical goods delivery, Goods Receipt confirmation is performed against the Purchase Order. During Goods receipt serial numbers are noted and asset tags created. Further Asset Master is created in the system for initiating the capitalization process. Upon receipt of invoice from the supplier, Supplier Invoice is created and posted in the system by the Accounts Payable team and released for payment.

Potential Roadblocks

This section discusses challenges which can be encountered in execution of the above process.

  • Asset creation timing:

SAP Ariba Guided Buying doesn‚Äôt require asset master to be created at the time of Purchase Requisition creation for fixed asset. But SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition requires Asset ID to be entered in the Purchase Requisition and Purchase Order for the Account Assignment Category (AAC) A- Asset. This results in failure when Purchase Requisition is replicated from SAP Ariba Guided Buying to S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

From process perspective it might not be desirable to create Fixed Assets so early in the process as the delivered quantity can vary from the Purchase Requisition/ Purchase Order quantity, thus ending up with orphan Fixed Asset master data.

  • Limit of number of account assignments:

There is a limit of 99 account assignments (in this case asset ids) which can be assigned to a Purchase Order line item.

  • Partial receipt and value distribution:

In case of partial receipt or multiple receipts against the purchase order, value should be distributed corresponding to actual receipt quantity (i.e. ((PO Item Net Value/ PO Item Quantity) x Quantity Received). But by default, total PO Item Net Value is distributed among receipt quantity, which leads to incorrect valuation in case of partial receipt quantity.

  • Asset assignment at Goods Receipt:

Asset assignment can only be done in Purchase Order or Supplier Invoice. Asset Assignment fields are display only in Post Goods Receipt. Also available Goods Receipt APIs and BADIs do not provide capability to update the Asset Information

  • Asset capitalization timing control:

By default Asset Valuation happens at the time of Supplier Invoice creation. But there could be a business need for asset valuation to be done at the time of Goods Receipt.

Potential Solutions 

  • Asset creation timing:

Account Assignment Category: A-Asset, which is delivered as part of standard configuration in Configuration Activity ‚ÄûMaintain Account Assignment Categories‚Äú has ‚ÄûAsset‚Äú field marked as Mandatory Entry (Figure1 Pt1), thus requiring asset assignment at the time of Purchase Requisition/ Purchase Order creation.  As standard delivered configuration cannot be changed, a custom Account Assignment Category: Z-Asset Mod (Figure2 Pt1) needs to be created with this field being Optional Entry. This will allow the Fixed Asset Purchase Requisition/ Purchase Order to be created without the Asset assignment and can be added later in the process. 

 

 

  • Limit of number of account assignments:

The number of account assignments per Purchase Requisition/ Purchase Order item is limited to 99. This is documented as part of KB Note: 2681590 - Multiple account assignment has limit of 99 lines - SAP for Me. 

Generally, the procured asset quantity will not be more than 99 units per line item, but in rare case where it is, then multiple line items need to be created with each line maximum quantity of 99 units

  • Partial receipt and value distribution:

By default, Account Assignment Category: A-Asset, Distribution is set to ‚Äû1- Distribution on Quantity Basis‚Äú and Partial Invoice is set to ‚Äû2- Apportion IR quantities to GR quantities proportionately‚Äú (See Figure 1 Pt2). This causes the total Purchase Order Item net value distributed among receipt quantity, which leads to incorrect valuation in case of partial quantity receipt.

To solve this issue, in Maintain Account Assignment Categories configuration activity, Distribution should be set to ‚Äû1-Distribution on Quantity Basis‚Äú and Partial Invoice to ‚Äû1-Apportion IR quantities to GR quantities one after another‚Äú (see Figure 2 Pt2). This will distribute partial Purchase Order Item net value corresponding to the quantities received. Figure 3 shows based on the Account Assignment Category configuration how Distribution and Partial Invoice fields are defaulted in Purchase Order Line Item ‚Äì Account Assignment

 

  • Asset assignment at Goods Receipt:

Account Assignment fields are visible but not editable in the Post Goods Receipt app. Also, these fields cannot be updated via the Goods Receipt API or Goods Receipt BADI.

Custom App using Embedded ABAP needs to be built for capturing the receipt quantity along with asset information with reference to Purchase Order. This app will capture Asset Class, Asset Description, Cost Center and Asset Serial Numbers corresponding to the Goods Receipt quantity. Upon saving this will trigger the following APIs to accomplish the following tasks:

1. Create Assets in the system with Serial Number (API: Fixed Asset - Master Data)

Asset Master is created with serial number capture based on the receipt quantity

2. Update Purchase Order with Asset Information (API: Purchase Order - Account Assignment)

As Asset Account assignment cannot be directly updated in Post Goods Receipt, the Purchase Order is updated with the asset account assignment. This will then flow to Supplier Invoice, when it is created with reference to the Purchase Order

3. Goods Receipt Confirmation (API: Material Document - Read, Create))

Goods Receipt confirmation and posting is done

This allows the goods receipt entry to be done once via the custom application, which in turn creates the asset master, updates the purchase order with asset information and post goods receipt.

  • Asset capitalization timing control:

Whether Valuation happens at the time of Goods Receipt or at the time of Supplier Invoice, posting is controlled via the ‚ÄûGR Non-Valuated‚Äú flag in the Account Assignment Category.

By default in Account Assignment Category = A-Asset, the valuation in marked to happen at the time of Supplier Invoice posting as ‚ÄûGR Non-Valuated‚Äú flag is checked (Figure 1 Pt3).

If valuation needs to happen at the time of Goods Receipt, then ‚ÄûGr Non-Valuated‚Äú flag needs to be changed to unchecked (Figure 2 Pt3).

Conclusion:

Business needs flexibility on when the asset needs to be created in the Procure To Pay process for Fixed Assets. This blog provided some tips and tricks on controlling the timing of fixed asset creation, timing of asset valuation and deriving the correct asset valuation in case of partial receipt.

entry.title: Deep Dive into SAP CPI Adapters: Synchronous vs Asynchronous Communication Patterns
entry.content:
Introduction

As integration technologies continue to grow, SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) plays a pivotal role in enabling seamless connectivity between different systems. It serves as a powerful middleware that enables seamless data exchange between SAP and SAP systems or between SAP and non-SAP systems. One of the core components that make this integration possible is the adapter framework, which defines how messages are exchanged across different protocols, formats, and applications.

Adapters in CPI act as bridges between the integration layer and external systems. Depending on the business scenario, these adapters can follow either a synchronous or asynchronous communication pattern, influencing how data is sent and received between different systems.

This blog provides a deep technical dive into these communication patterns and explores some of the most widely used synchronous and asynchronous adapters in SAP CPI, along with their meanings, purposes, key features, and real-world examples.

Understanding Communication Patterns in SAP CPI

Synchronous Communication

In a synchronous communication pattern, the sender sends a request to the receiver system and waits for a direct response before proceeding further. This pattern is suitable for real-time transactions or interactive systems that require immediate confirmation or data retrieval. It is best for urgent matters, as it allows for immediate feedback.
Typical use cases include API integrations, data validation requests, or real-time service calls.

Example: An HTTP API call from a mobile app to CPI to fetch customer details instantly.

Asynchronous Communication

In asynchronous communication, the sender and receiver are loosely coupled ‚Äî the sender sends the message to the receiver system but doesn‚Äôt wait for an immediate response from it. Messages are usually queued or processed later, allowing higher flexibility and scalability. This communication is more flexible, giving participants time to respond thoughtfully.
This pattern is ideal for batch processing, file-based data transfers, or event-driven systems.

Example: Uploading a file to an SFTP server where CPI processes the data in the background.

Synchronous Adapters in SAP CPI

1. HTTP Adapter

Definition

The HTTP Adapter in SAP CPI facilitates communication using the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP). It is one of the most commonly used adapters that allows CPI to connect with REST-based APIs, web services, and applications. HTTP is the primary protocol for interbusiness message exchange.  Applications can send messages to a server by sending HTTP POST or HTTP GET requests to a specified HTTP URL.
HTTP Adapter supports various HTTP methods such as GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE, enabling flexible integration with both SAP and non-SAP systems.
It is required in scenarios where request-response framework is used.

Purpose / Usage

  • To connect CPI with RESTful APIs or web services.
  • For real-time integrations requiring instant acknowledgment.
  • To send and receive data in JSON, XML, or plain text formats.

Key Features

  • Supports both client (sender) and server (receiver) configurations.
  • Compatible with REST APIs and lightweight JSON payloads.
  • Can be used to expose CPI iFlows as HTTP endpoints for external consumption.

Example Use Case Scenario

A mobile app triggers an HTTP POST request to CPI to check product availability in real-time. CPI connects to SAP S/4HANA, retrieves the stock status, and returns it immediately as an HTTP response.

2. OData Adapter

Definition

The OData Adapter in SAP CPI is designed for communication with systems that expose data via OData (Open Data Protocol) ‚Äî a standardized REST-based protocol developed by Microsoft and heavily used in SAP products like SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, and SAP C4C. This adapter works with V4 (which is the latest version) and also with previous backward versions V2 and V3. 
OData services provide metadata-driven, resource-oriented access to data entities, allowing CPI to interact with backend systems using structured operations such as query, create, update, and delete (CRUD). This is mostly used for performing task on the data like creating, reading, deleting etc.
It simplifies real-time data exchange and reduces the need for manual API definition, as metadata is auto-generated from the service URL. The REST APIs of this adapter are easy to consume. THE OData metadata enables the formation of client proxies and tools,

Purpose / Usage

  • To integrate with SAP systems that expose OData services.
  • To perform CRUD operations on data entities.
  • Suitable for real-time scenarios involving business data retrieval or updates.

Key Features

  • Automatic entity mapping based on service metadata.
  • Supports OData V2 and V4 protocols.
  • Allows query options like $filter, $expand, $select for precise data retrieval.
  • Compatible with authentication methods like OAuth 2.0, Basic, and Principal Propagation.

Example Use Case Scenario

A CPI iFlow retrieves employee details from SAP SuccessFactors through an OData GET request and returns the structured response to a corporate HR portal instantly.

3. SOAP Adapter

Definition

The SOAP Adapter supports communication through SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) ‚Äî SOAP is an older protocol compared to HTTP/OData, but still widely used in enterprises, especially for secure and structured messaging. The SOAP adapter is used to connect with systems that expose SOAP web services. A SOAP adapter can be configured for either synchronous or asynchronous communication, depending on the requirements of the integration scenario. The choice depends on factors like whether an immediate response is needed and how the system should handle potential delays. 
It is often used in enterprise-grade integrations that require strict adherence to data structure, message validation, and security policies.
The adapter supports WSDL (Web Services Description Language)-based configuration, enabling CPI to easily integrate with legacy systems and services that still rely on SOAP endpoints. This adapter exposes the inbound endpoints for accepting the requests that are addressed to a particular URL. The requests are then passed to the next step in the integration flow as part of the message payload, along with the SOAP headers.

Purpose / Usage

  • To integrate CPI with SOAP-based or WSDL-driven web services.
  • Commonly used where schema validation, security, and transactional reliability are critical.
  • Ideal for synchronous request-response integrations.

Key Features

  • Supports WS-Security for message-level encryption and authentication.
  • Handles large XML payloads efficiently.
  • Provides built-in SOAP fault handling and retry mechanisms.
  • Compatible with both 1.1 and 1.2 SOAP versions.

Example Use Case Scenario

A CPI iFlow sends a SOAP request to an external credit bureau service to perform a customer credit check and receives the score synchronously before proceeding with loan approval.

4. ProcessDirect Adapter

Definition

The ProcessDirect Adapter allows direct, high-performance communication between integration flows within the same tenant in SAP CPI. This is basically use to split a very large integration flow into different smaller integration flows that can further be managed and controlled by different users. This adapter is being used by the developers when they want to boost the performance of their integration flow. Its like one splitted iflow becomes the producer iflow and the other becomes the consumer iflow. So the consumer iflow will consume the message that is being processed and passed by the producer iflow. 
It provides an internal channel for message exchange, eliminating the need for external network transmission.
This adapter is typically used for modular integration design, where a parent iflow can invoke multiple child iflows (subprocesses) synchronously to reuse logic or perform specific tasks.

Purpose / Usage

  • To enable communication between iFlows in the same tenant.
  • For modular design and reuse of business logic.
  • To enhance performance by avoiding HTTP overhead.

Key Features

  • Operates synchronously by default.
  • No additional authentication required since it‚Äôs internal to the tenant.
  • High-performance and low-latency communication.
  • Simplifies maintenance by promoting modularization.

Example Use Case Scenario

In a company, if one iFlow handles ‚Äúemployee onboarding‚Äù and another iFlow handles ‚Äúsending welcome emails,‚Äù So when a new employee will get onboarded then the onboarding iFlow can directly trigger the email iFlow using ProcessDirect without repeating the same logic.

 

Asynchronous Adapters in SAP CPI

1. SFTP Adapter

Definition

The SFTP (Secure File Transfer Protocol) Adapter is used for file-based data exchange between CPI and external systems via a secure SSH connection. It ensures encrypted, secure transmission of files between systems. SFTP is widely used in batch-oriented integrations, particularly when integrating with legacy systems or business partners who exchange data through flat files such as CSV, XML, or JSON. It ensures end-to-end security during file transfers and supports large data volumes. Using this adapter as a source will allow you to read data from a file as well as fetch a particular file from a directory. Using this adapter as a target will allow you to transfer data to a specified file on the server.

Purpose / Usage

  • For secure file transfers to and from CPI.
  • Common in B2B integrations and scheduled data exchanges.
  • Used in scenarios with delayed or periodic processing.

Key Features

  • Supports both sender and receiver modes.
  • Encryption through SSH keys or passwords.
  • File archiving, deletion, and duplicate handling options.
  • Compatible with large file sizes and different payload formats.

Example Use Case Scenario

Think about a supplier who provides a large retailer with a daily stock availability report. Instead of emailing, the supplier drops a CSV file into a secure SFTP folder. The retailer‚Äôs system picks it up automatically.

2. FTP Adapter

Definition

The FTP (File Transfer Protocol) Adapter enables CPI to exchange files with systems over standard FTP or FTPS (FTP Secure). It transfers files to any public server in either binary or ASCII format. FTP is similar to SFTP but less secure because it doesn‚Äôt encrypt data. It‚Äôs still used in many organizations for bulk file transfers where security is not the highest priority. This adapter supports streaming for transferring very large data files. It also supports host key authentication, public key authentication and multilevel authentication.
While similar to SFTP, it uses SSL/TLS-based encryption in FTPS mode or plain transfer in FTP mode. It‚Äôs typically used in internal system communications or non-critical file transfers where performance and simplicity are prioritized over encryption strength.

Purpose / Usage

  • For exchanging data files with internal or external systems.
  • Used for scheduled or bulk data integration scenarios.
  • Common in environments where traditional FTP servers are still used.

Key Features

  • Supports FTP and FTPS modes.
  • Configurable directory paths and file filters.
  • Can read, write, and delete files on remote servers.
  • Lightweight and easy to configure for internal networks.

Example Use Case Scenario

Weather stations upload temperature readings via FTP to a central government database, where data is less sensitive but needs to be transferred quickly and in bulk.

3. Mail Adapter

Definition

The Mail Adapter enables CPI to send or receive emails using SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) for outbound communication and POP3/IMAP for inbound processing. The Mail adapter allows integration with email systems like Gmail, Outlook, or corporate mail servers. It can send and receive mails as part of integration flows. It supports attachments and can handle HTML or plain text content, allowing integration scenarios where notifications, alerts, or data files are exchanged through email systems.

Purpose / Usage

  • To send automated email notifications or reports.
  • To process incoming emails with attachments.
  • Used in system-to-human or human-to-system communication flows.

Key Features

  • Supports multiple email protocols (SMTP, IMAP, POP3).
  • Allows custom subject lines, body templates, and attachments.
  • Compatible with secure connections (TLS/SSL).
  • Can poll inboxes periodically for new messages.
  • If a mail server is communicating with the mail adapter, We can configure security settings to encrypt or decrypt the messages.

Example Use Case Scenario

An iFlow automatically sends an email alert with attached error logs to the system administrator whenever a process fails in CPI. Another example can be let's say whenever you order food from Zomato or Swiggy, you immediately get a confirmation email. That‚Äôs an example of system-triggered emails using integration. Or lets say when you book a flight ticket online, you instantly get a confirmation email with your ticket details. That‚Äôs exactly how mail adapters are used to automatically send communication to customers.

4. JMS Adapter

Definition

The JMS (Java Message Service) Adapter enables asynchronous communication using message queues and topics. It ensures reliable, persistent, and decoupled message delivery between systems.
It is particularly useful in large-scale, event-driven integrations where message sequencing, retry logic, and guaranteed delivery are essential. This adapter works well with external JMS applications, Web servers and Java EE applications.

Purpose / Usage

  • To manage queued message exchanges in asynchronous scenarios.
  • To decouple senders and receivers for scalability and resilience.
  • Suitable for load balancing and guaranteed delivery use cases.

Key Features

  • Supports queues and topics for message broadcasting.
  • Provides guaranteed delivery, persistence, and retries.
  • Enables distributed and parallel message consumption.
  • Integrates with other CPI adapters and enterprise message brokers.

Example Use Case Scenario

A CPI iFlow pushes order events into a JMS queue. Another iFlow picks up these messages later to update the SAP backend, ensuring reliable, asynchronous order processing.

 

Conclusion

Choosing between synchronous and asynchronous adapters in SAP CPI is not just a technical decision. It‚Äôs a strategic choice that directly impacts the performance and scalability of the integration flows across different systems. Each communication pattern serves a distinct purpose: synchronous adapters like HTTP, OData, SOAP, and ProcessDirect enable request‚Äìresponse integrations, ideal for scenarios requiring instant acknowledgment or data retrieval. On the other hand, asynchronous adapters such as SFTP, FTP, Mail, and JMS ensure flexibility in high-volume, event-driven, or batch-oriented integrations.

A well-designed integration architecture in SAP CPI typically leverages a hybrid approach, where both synchronous and asynchronous communications are used .This combination allows organizations to balance performance, fault tolerance, speed and resource optimization effectively.

Furthermore, understanding the strengths and weaknesses of each adapter empowers integration developers to choose the right tool for the right situation. For instance, HTTP adapter is used for sending and receiving data over HTTP protocols and is used mainly for request-response cases. On the other hand, Let's say, We have SFTP adapter which is used for securely transfer files between various systems. Another example, Let's say, We have OData adapter which can be used for integrating SAP systems like SAP S/4HANA or Successfactors, and then we have Mail adapter which allows integration with email systems like Gmail, Outlook or corporate mail servers. So every adapter has its own feature and functionality and thus should be use when a proper situation arises for it.

As enterprises continue to grow and use the cloud-first architectures and systems, the role of adapters in SAP CPI becomes even more crucial. By mastering these adapters and their communication models, integration specialists can build scalable and secure iFlows that support digital transformation goals with agility and confidence. In essence, the right adapter strategy not only streamlines system connectivity but also lays the foundation for an intelligent integration ecosystem within SAP‚Äôs cloud platform.
